author: Alice Sholl
title: It’s time women stopped putting up with toilet queues
text:
Just half an hour to go (Picture: Matt Cardy/Getty Images) So why is it we put up with it so quietly? 
Perhaps because it’s a taboo topic, or maybe because when it comes to physical discomforts such as a period or hormonal pain, we’re used to ‘just dealing with it’. 
Take periods, for example – despite 52% of women having experienced period pain badly enough to affect their ability to work, only 27% have told their boss period pain was responsible . 
Which is hardly surprising. I believe as a culture, we take women’s pain less seriously than men’s. 
Even doctors; studies have found that while men wait an average of 49 minutes before being treated for abdominal pain, women will wait for 65 minutes for the same symptoms. 
In other words, we’re reluctant to complain about things regarding our physical discomfort because we’re used to them being brushed off as over reactions.
Which does make me wonder – men, would you put up with a venue that doesn’t let you go to the toilet?
Admittedly, some (often old) venues simply haven’t been built by or to accommodate women .
This is thanks to something that has a reputation for screwing over women, it’s called The Past. It was a time before women were invited so readily into pubs, clubs and the like, or perhaps it has something to do with architecture being so male-dominated .
And while I can’t ask businesses to magic a new room into an existing building, for those building new designs or those that have enough space to physically fit in more cubicles… well, I don’t think you have a leg to stand on.
As with many aspects of public life, toilets are something that has been designed to suit men (a little like when we found out air conditioning guidelines have been created to suit 40-year-old gentleman in the 60s).

And, like this, as long as women don’t push for change and it continues to be the easiest option for businesses, they’ll continue to build toilets to the basic minimum requirements because, well, that’s the way they’ve always done it. 
So perhaps it’s time we held businesses’ toilets to the same standard as their drinks, food or whatever it is they’re providing us. 
Or we could just wait for gender segregated toilets to disappear altogether . 
Either way, seriously – hurry up – we’ve gotta pee.
